comments.commentBody:
John,
If you want a block of American cheese just go to the deli section of your supermarket or to a non-Jewish deli (usually a German deli, if you can find one). There you can ask that they cut you the American cheese in one piece.
I ask at the deli for a block of approx how many lbs. of cheese I want.

This has a wonderful flavor, however, my crusty top turned hard and brittle in spots. I could not find American cheese in a block so I bought a 12-oz pkg of Kraft slices and tried to hand grate, which did not go well. I wonder if the author didn't want to come right out and say "Velveeta", which s what I will use next time, along with more careful monitoring of the top crust. Oddly, the bottom did not turn crusty at all. I baked this in a white porcelain 9x13 which BARELY held it.
Interesting you chose "5 cents of every dollar" instead of merely using 5%. 5% is quite substantial. This isn't a guy wanting to compensate college kids, it's a guy who wants to get rich.

How about we just get rid of the abusive and corrupt NCAA?

And we take athletics out of universities?

Matt Ng, what the heck are you arguing about? Many Patriots fans, including in the days preceding the playoff game last year, rued the potential match-up with the Ravens and said they would have preferred a game against Pittsburgh.

In his message above, Marc S. never said anything about cheating. Given the recent court proceedings involving a certain former Patriots player, it is ironic that Pats fans are always so quick to talk about Ravens and crime. Let's focus on the football, huh? Go Steelers (this year only).
Yes, very much.
Not a Ravens fan by any means, having grown up in Pittsburgh, but one Aaron Hernandez more than offsets a lot of Ray Rices.

Not mentioned, of course, is that for the first time in eight years, neither team has the Ravens to worry about. That must have a significant impact on the entire AFC, especially with the Patriots knowing they won't have their number one antagonist heading their way. And the way things have played out with the Ravens, they very well may not be a factor for two or three more seasons. Yea, as a Ravens' fan, it hurts watching from the sideline.

.
BUSHISM can be a positive or negative word as well.

I believe the current deciding factor in the swing states is, who would you rather have a beer with. Mr. Bush, with his inferior college education, never came across on TV as someone with PRESIDENTS in his lineage. John Kerry, on the other hand, was fluent in French, which was held against him.

Plus, GW Bush had that whole irreverent outlaw thing going on, with the daughters and their fake IDs (both of whom are now admirable women), plus the wife who drove into another car, killing the occupant. (She's admirable too.) Some people found this relatable, others looked down their noses at the guy. I believe the BUSHISM in the clue was directed at the latter group.

(Other US public figures who were fluent in French: Franklin (beer lover), Jefferson (wine), both Adamses, Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy, and Mitt Romney (who doesn't drink beer).)

Complicating the score keeping at home is the fact that Reagan was a Democrat during his first marriage.

HOOVERVILLE is a strange word; in much of the world, HOOVER was far more famous for relieving hunger than for contributing to it.
Seems like you've found the cloud in the silver lining here...Typical whiney Jets fan.
Sheet pan? You can't make this in a sheet pan.
Absolutely!
For households that don't eat pork, would you substitute turkey sausage and beef salami for the meats?

This wasn't greasy at all; it's a little heavy on cheese but definitely not too cheesey. I thought it was delicious and rich & buttery tasting. Everyone who is doubling (and more) the milk is missing the point of this recipe. Your experiment will not cook down into the same rich dish at all. If I felt the need to make such a massive alteration to a recipe, I would simply pass the recipe by and find one more to my liking. There is no shortage of mac & cheese recipes on the web.
Tim, did you mean India's Prime Minister, Narebdra Modi? The President of India is Pranab Mukherjee.

Val in Brooklyn, NY to Tim B in Seattle
Well, Mr. McKibbon managed to both pretty well. The reality check is the rain on the parade. You mentioned overpopulation in your comment. In case I missed it, did any of the world leaders at the Climate Talks mention overpopulation?

Submitted 12/14/15@1:57 a.m. e.s.t.

Yeah，you are right!But I think "proportionate responsibility and shared duty" is more feasible in this period of time!We shouldn't do something that is beyond our reality and turn a blind eye to the poor!For getting something,you have to give something out!Another problem is supervision and investigation!Long road,Buddy!

I was struck when watching live the commentary from the world's leaders, with India's president speaking about 'sustainable development'. Some in the developing world want what we have here in the West, yet by seeking to emulate what we have done, I read that five Planet Earths would be required, to have sufficient resources for all the human beings currently living if every one of us wanted economies and comforts as we have here, and to avoid incessantly rising temperatures.

True, it seems unfair to those who are 'late to the party', but our planet is urgently urging us to curtail our profligate ways, regardless of where we live on this wondrous orb. It is the two twin challenges which face us, those of over consumption and overpopulation, which will be paramount for us as a species to face in the decades and centuries ahead.

We should never lose sight as well of the importance of an intact and habitable Earth to all other living species.

.
JFC, I read that book and the next 5 from the same author. I note that your guy lived in Connecticut and Maryland, as you did; in fact, his renown was due in part to an Annapolis-based distributor.

Suejean's new fellow citizens have had only one King with your name. We have had only one PRESIDENT with your guy's first name.

The impact to how we drive our economies and live our lives would be very substantial beyond the cost of methods we’ve already imposed on ourselves – particularly as the efforts with eventual positive economic payback represent substantially less than 50% of the total investment for the U.S. Payback for developing economies would be harder to achieve over longer strategic periods, as the proportional investment is much higher.

The lift for the U.S. and other developed economies is great indeed. For developing, large industrialized and semi-industrialized economies such as China’s, India’s, Russia’s, projected to pollute the most, the cost of meeting meaningful commitments truly will be immense.

To me, the value of Paris is that for the first time we have a global benchmark that can serve as the basis for further negotiation, on the commitments themselves as well as on means for assisting each nation to meet them. But left to themselves, weaker economies will not come close to satisfying even the commitments the author characterizes as “falling short”. Assuming that for any of this to work the West will need to pay for much of it, the notion that substantial gains will be made in ten or even in 35 years is fantasy – this is a multi-generational effort if it’s anything.

Accordingly, the next “Paris”, that should be arranged immediately, should focus on defining the means we can mobilize not to beat back climate change but to LIVE WITH IT.

My other comment notwithstanding (it was intended to be tongue in cheek, though may not have come across that way), I don't see how the theme is about "politics" in any sense that you wouldn't discuss it with family. Mostly it's stuff that kids will learn in school, hardly something that should be unspoken.

All families are different. Mine ranges from one end of the political spectrum to the other, yet we still find a way to talk about (and argue) politics -- and still get along.

Sports, though, that's where you need to be careful what you say....

If you're not familiar with "American Cheese", it is sold in every supermarket all over the USA, usually pre-sliced for sandwiches. The package will be clearly marked "American Cheese". That's what it's called: "American Cheese." Kraft is one very common brand.

Because the leaders of the Republican Party, such as Senator Mitch McConnell, vowed from the start of Obama's presidency to make him a one-term President and opposed almost every policy he proposed.  A large amount of the affordable care act was based on the earlier version passed under Mitt Romney as Governor of Massachusetts and many of the concepts came from Republican think tanks.  The Republicans have almost never offered constructive participation with the Obama Administration.  The general position has been "Just say NO" even to the extent of shutting down the government.  The press has generally failed to call out the Republicans.  So I guess your screed is really a form of satire.
I made the recipe and added double the cayenne; it was too much for me. I think the low ratio of milk intensified the peppery impact of the cayenne. Next time I will stick with the 1/8 tsp specified.

How about this clue:
Preposition, for example?

ON, E.G.

I followed the directions the first time, and it was great. The next time I made it, I wanted more squash, so I sauted 1/2 diced squash (about 2 cups) in the butter and olive oil, and when it was almost done, I put it in the polenta as it was cooking. I put the fennel and rosemary into the onions as they cooked. I liked it even more.

When I was in 7th-grade social studies class, they taught us somewhat about tribal taboos, based on Margaret Mead's research around the world. I distinctly remember scoffing at the teacher (internally): "That's just nonsense! how can they make people not talk about something or not say certain words?" I thought the whole idea of tribal taboo was ridiculous...until that evening, when, seated at the family dinner table, I realized: politics (taboo) - religion (taboo) - money (taboo) - relationships (taboo) - employment (taboo) - things you are excited about (taboo) - things you aren't excited about (taboo) -
The list of discussable items was short indeed. I had simply never noticed before!

Huguenot torte! Yes, others have said the same thing. Charleston, SC cookbooks would not be the 'real' thing without a Huguenot torte recipe.

My mouth waters just thinking of this rich and luscious dessert. It's wonderful without any topping.

Add a special topping...and sublime moves into another category of absolutely divinely rich and meant for royalty! (And surely that includes you and me!!)

So, yesterday we had the memorial service for a lovely lady whose husband survives her after 56 years of marriage. One of the little stories told in the service was how the wife got a call (this was about 4 years back) telling her that the husband had fallen from a ladder while making some repairs to one of the church buildings (not his job, just his hobby), breaking his arm. Her response?
"What was the old goat doing up there in the first place???"

.
Exactly!

Right after the internal investigative report on the reluctance of NYT to do an objective and fair examination of Martin O'Malley's platform. After all, Gov. O'Malley never ran in a statewide Democratic Party primary only to refuse the Democratic Party nomination (as Sanders has done). Gov. O'Malley is a longtime Democrat seeking his party's nomination, and he deserves to have his platform evaluated.

Then NYT should move on to candidates who became Democrats in 2015.

Investigative so called journalism is not not what it used to be. In the last two decades  with Clinton followed by Bush/ Cheney, even the NYT times forgot  to seriously investigate anything that mattered. First and fore most  was Bill Clinton and his freaking  signing the repeal of the Glass-Stegall Act. Which  deregulated the banking system and the  Fundamentally Flawed Economic System descended into the sewer. Then followed by the Bush/ Cheney   BS untenable war on terror at home, Afghanistan / Pakistan  and the fraud war on Iraq with falsified and  manufactured evidence.  That even NYT went along  without  questioning . let alone  any real investigation. Before that it was that two bit senile old actor  and his favorite freedom fighter, one bin Laden.

Strange language, Hungarian. Karfiol is a variant of the Romance language cabbage-flower pattern. (Caulis is Latin for cabbage stem. Caulis also gives us "kale," by the way.)
But Hungarian has a native term for cabbage unrelated to the Latin, fejes káposzta. I have no idea where that comes from. It's Hungarian.

The closest to "karfiol" seems to be the Polish, "kalafior." The r and l are swapped just because, I guess. Polish also uses a native Slavic word for cabbage. Perhaps the word was borrowed from Poland. They may have borrowed from the Italian, "cavolfiore."

"Carciofo" comes from the Arabic, kursuf.

Earlier today I was talking with a priest outside church about the new movie "Spotlight," which is all about the Boston Globe's investigation of priests who sexually abused kids. One of the reasons the scandal was so big and went on for so long was because no one -- not the church, not the press, NOBODY -- wanted to talk about it.

I think we should have taboos against certain acts -- like what the priests were doing.

Taboos about what we allow ourselves to talk about -- generally not a good thing.
